text:
Hi. I am looking at the source of <https://github.com/chakravala/Fatou.jl/blob/master/src/Fatou.jl|Fatou.jl> to understand how their implementation of the Mandelbrot visualization is faster. I have a couple of questions:
1. The `n` variable they have used is for horizontal grid points. Is that the same as the num of pixels/coordinates calculated? So it calculates for 176x176 pixels by default?
2. It's `N` is UInt8, and it means the maximum iteration per coordinate (or complex coordinate) is just 255. I've read that you would need atleast a value of 1000 for max iteration for the visualization to be quite accurate. Is this actually restricted to 255 or am I just confusing `N` with max iteration?
3. Does anyone have a fast Mandelbrot visualization in Julia (without using GPU) which runs well for 1920x1080 images?

to understand how their implementation of the Mandelbrot visualization is faster. I have a couple of questions:
The `n` variable they have used is for horizontal grid points. Is that the same as the num of pixels/coordinates calculated? So it calculates for 176x176 pixels by default?

It's `N` is UInt8, and it means the maximum iteration per coordinate (or complex coordinate) is just 255. I've read that you would need atleast a value of 1000 for max iteration for the visualization to be quite accurate. Is this actually restricted to 255 or am I just confusing `N` with max iteration?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>
